devdoc.author: pcaversaccio
devdoc.custom:security: Signatures must not be used as unique identifiers since the `ecrecover` EVM precompile allows for malleable (non-unique) signatures (see EIP-2: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2) or signatures can be malleablised using EIP-2098: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2098.
devdoc.license: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0 only

__init__().details: To omit the opcodes for checking the `msg.value` in the creation-time EVM bytecode, the constructor is declared as `payable`.

recover_sig(bytes32,bytes).details: Recovers the signer address from a message digest `hash` and the signature `signature`.

params.hash: The 32-byte message digest that was signed.

to_data_with_intended_validator_hash(add.details: Returns an Ethereum signed data with `validator` as the intended validator and a maximum 1,024-byte payload `data`.

params.data: The maximum 1,024-byte data to be signed.

to_data_with_intended_validator_hash_sel.details: Returns an Ethereum signed data with this contract as the intended validator and a maximum 1,024-byte payload `data`.

params.data: The maximum 1,024-byte data to be signed.

to_eth_signed_message_hash(bytes32).details: Returns an Ethereum signed message from a 32-byte message digest `hash`.

to_typed_data_hash(bytes32,bytes32).details: Returns an Ethereum signed typed data from a 32-byte `domain_separator` and a 32-byte `struct_hash`.

params.domain_separator: The 32-byte domain separator that is used as part of the EIP-712 encoding scheme.
params.struct_hash: The 32-byte struct hash that is used as part of the EIP-712 encoding scheme. See the definition: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-712#definition-of-hashstruct.

returns._0: bytes32 The 32-byte Ethereum signed typed data.

devdoc.title: Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA) Functions

recover_sig(bytes32,bytes).notice: WARNING: This function is vulnerable to a kind of signature malleability due to accepting EIP-2098 compact signatures in addition to the traditional 65-byte signature format. The potentially affected contracts are those that implement signature reuse or replay protection by marking the signature itself as used rather than the signed message or a nonce included in it. A user may take a signature that has already been submitted, submit it again in a different form, and bypass this protection. Also, see OpenZeppelin's security advisory for more information: https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/openzeppelin-contracts/security/advisories/GHSA-4h98-2769-gh6h.

to_data_with_intended_validator_hash(add.notice: This function structures the data according to the version `0x00` of EIP-191: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-191#version-0x00.

to_data_with_intended_validator_hash_sel.notice: This function structures the data according to the version `0x00` of EIP-191: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-191#version-0x00.

to_eth_signed_message_hash(bytes32).notice: This function returns a 32-byte hash that corresponds to the one signed with the JSON-RPC method: https://ethereum.org/en/developers/docs/apis/json-rpc/#eth_sign. This method is part of EIP-191: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-191.

to_typed_data_hash(bytes32,bytes32).notice: This function returns a 32-byte hash that corresponds to the one signed with the JSON-RPC method: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-712#specification-of-the-eth_signtypeddata-json-rpc. This method is part of EIP-712: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-712.

userdoc.notice: These functions can be used to verify that a message was signed by the holder of the private key of a given address. Additionally, we provide helper functions to handle signed data in Ethereum contracts based on EIP-191: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-191. The implementation is inspired by OpenZeppelin's implementation here: https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/openzeppelin-contracts/blob/master/contracts/utils/cryptography/ECDSA.sol.
